title: Trump blew lid off illusion, Modi nowhere to be seen: Rahul as bourses plunge over tariff turmoil
story_summary: Congress leader Rahul Gandhi criticized Prime Minister Narendra Modi, stating he was "nowhere to be seen" as Indian stock markets plunged significantly on Monday. Gandhi attributed the market turmoil to U.S. President Donald Trump's reciprocal tariffs, claiming Trump had "blown the lid off the illusion" of India's economic strength. He emphasized the need for India to build a resilient, production-based economy that works for all Indians. The sharp decline saw the BSE Sensex fall by over 2,226 points, its largest single-day drop in 10 months, while the NSE Nifty also tumbled. This mirrored a global market sell-off triggered by fears of an economic slowdown due to the U.S.-China trade tensions following Trump's tariff announcements and subsequent retaliation.

title: Video of Kuno staff offering cheetahs water: KNP begins inquiry over staff indiscipline, violation of norms
story_summary: Authorities at Madhya Pradesh's Kuno National Park (KNP) have launched an inquiry into staff indiscipline after a video surfaced showing personnel offering water to a cheetah and her cubs. The incident, which occurred near the park's boundary where cheetah Jwala and her cubs were close to human habitation, involved a daily wager driver giving water in a bowl. Officials stated this violated clear protocols requiring unauthorized staff to maintain distance from the animals. The staff were reportedly trying to lure the cheetahs back into the forest. The video sparked concerns about adherence to safety norms and wildlife handling procedures within the park, which is home to cheetahs translocated from Namibia and South Africa. Disciplinary action against the involved staff is underway.

title: Nirmala Sitharaman to visit the U.K., Austria from April 8
story_summary: Union Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman is scheduled to visit the United Kingdom and Austria from April 8th to 13th, 2025. During her trip, she will participate in the 13th Ministerial round of the India-UK Economic and Financial Dialogue (EFD), co-chairing it with UK Chancellor Rachel Reeves. The dialogue focuses on financial collaboration, investment, financial services, regulations, UPI interlinkages, taxation, and illicit financial flows. Key Indian priorities include cooperation in IFSC GIFT City, investment, insurance, FinTech, and mobilizing sustainable climate finance. Ms. Sitharaman will also hold bilateral meetings and engage with think tanks, investors, and business leaders in both nations. In Austria, she will meet government leaders and co-chair a session with CEOs to discuss investment collaboration.

title: BJP tops list of national parties with over ₹2,243 crore in donations in FY 2023-24: ADR
story_summary: The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) received the largest share of donations above ₹20,000 among national parties during the financial year 2023-24, according to a report by the Association for Democratic Reforms (ADR). The BJP declared over ₹2,243 crore from 8,358 donations, making up 88% of the total ₹2,544.28 crore declared by all national parties. This represented a 211% increase for the BJP compared to the previous fiscal year. The Indian National Congress was second with ₹281.48 crore, a 252% rise. Corporate sectors were the main source of funds, contributing nearly 89%. Prudent Electoral Trust was the top donor. The ADR report noted a sharp overall increase in large donations and called for stricter disclosure rules and scrutiny by tax authorities.

title: Myanmar at crossroads: crisis, aid and fight for stability
story_summary: Myanmar faces a compounded crisis following a 7.7-magnitude earthquake near Mandalay, which killed at least 2,000 people. This disaster exacerbates the instability stemming from the 2021 military coup. The military junta controls much of the earthquake-affected zone, complicating aid delivery. Junta leader Min Aung Hlaing has made an unusual appeal for international aid, despite the regime's history of resisting foreign help (e.g., post-Cyclone Nargis 2008) and facing Western sanctions over the coup and Rohingya crisis. The international community grapples with providing aid without legitimizing the junta. ASEAN, along with neighbours like India and China, are key to coordinating relief efforts, potentially via the AHA Centre. Recommendations include discreet engagement, urging a ceasefire, and reviving international coordination mechanisms.

title: Badlapur sexual assault case: HC directs FIR against cops responsible for custodial death of accused, orders SIT probe
story_summary: The Bombay High Court has ordered the Maharashtra government to file an FIR against five policemen implicated in the custodial death of Akshay Shinde. Shinde was accused in the Badlapur school sexual assault case. He was shot dead on September 23, 2024, while being transported by the police escort team. A magistrate's inquiry report suggested the possibility of a fake encounter. The High Court criticized the state's delay in lodging an FIR and mandated the formation of a Special Investigation Team (SIT) under the Joint Commissioner of Police (Crime) to investigate the incident thoroughly. The police maintained they acted in self-defense after Shinde allegedly tried to snatch a firearm. The court stressed that justice must be perceived to be done.

title: Supreme Court junks plea for 100% manual counting of VVPAT slips during polls
story_summary: The Supreme Court on Monday dismissed a petition seeking 100% manual counting of Voter Verifiable Paper Audit Trail (VVPAT) slips alongside the electronic count from EVM control units. A bench led by Chief Justice Sanjiv Khanna declined to intervene in a Delhi High Court judgment that had previously rejected the plea by Hans Raj Jain. The CJI remarked that the apex court had already settled similar issues in past rulings, affirming the reliability and security of Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) and VVPATs. The plea had also requested modifications to the VVPAT system design. The Delhi High Court had dismissed the initial petition citing the Supreme Court's decision in the ADR v. ECI case, considering the matter already decided.

title: Railways land-for-jobs 'scam': Supreme Court refuses to hear ED's plea against bail to Lalu aide
story_summary: The Supreme Court declined to entertain an Enforcement Directorate (ED) plea challenging the bail granted to Amit Katyal, a businessman linked to RJD chief Lalu Prasad Yadav, in the railways land-for-jobs money laundering case. The Delhi High Court had granted Katyal bail in September 2024. The Supreme Court bench questioned the ED's pursuit of Katyal when other primary accused persons remained unarrested. The High Court's bail order had previously criticized the ED's alleged "pick and choose" strategy, noting Katyal's cooperation during the investigation prior to his arrest in November 2023. The case involves allegations of land acquisition in exchange for Group D railway jobs during Lalu Prasad's tenure as Railway Minister (2004-2009).

title: IUML moves Supreme Court against Waqf Amendment Act of 2025
story_summary: The Indian Union Muslim League (IUML) has approached the Supreme Court to challenge the Waqf (Amendment) Act, 2025. The party argues that the amendments fundamentally alter the management, creation, and protection of Waqf properties, which are Islamic endowments for religious and charitable use. The IUML contends that the amended provisions impose arbitrary restrictions, increase state control, deviate from the religious nature of Waqf, and violate constitutional guarantees under Articles 14, 15, 25, and 26 (related to equality, non-discrimination, freedom of religion, and managing religious affairs). The party leadership expressed concerns that the amendments aim to undermine the Waqf Act and curtail the rights of the Muslim community.

title: Manipur cumulatively spent over six years under President’s Rule: Graphics
story_summary: Parliament confirmed the imposition of President's Rule in Manipur in early April 2025. Central rule was initially imposed on February 13, 2025, following the resignation of Chief Minister N. Biren Singh. This marks the 11th time President's Rule has been implemented in Manipur since 1967. Currently, Manipur is the only Indian state under President's Rule. Historically, the state has spent a cumulative total of over six and a half years under central administration. This duration ranks Manipur fourth among all states and Union Territories for the total time spent under President's Rule. Jammu and Kashmir leads with nearly 15 years, followed by Punjab (over 10 years) and Puducherry (over 7 years).

title: Two murder accused, cop, injured in encounter in Meerut
story_summary: Two men accused of murder, identified as Chhagga alias Balveer and Fauta alias Manmeet, were injured during a police encounter in Meerut's Hastinapur area on Sunday night, April 6, 2025. A police head constable, Tarun Malik, also sustained a gunshot injury in the exchange. The accused, each carrying a reward of ₹25,000, were allegedly involved in the April 2 murder of Parmjeet Singh. According to police, the encounter ensued after the suspects attempted to flee a routine check on a motorcycle, subsequently skidded, and opened fire when approached by officers. Police returned fire, injuring the accused. All injured individuals were hospitalized, and firearms were recovered from the scene.

title: Markets reacting predictably in 'tariffying' manner: Senior Congress leader Jairam Ramesh
story_summary: Reacting to a sharp fall in the stock market on Monday, April 7, 2025, senior Congress leader Jairam Ramesh criticized Prime Minister Narendra Modi. He attributed the market crash, where Sensex and Nifty fell over 5%, to recent reciprocal tariffs, stating markets were reacting "predictably in a tariffying manner." Ramesh drew parallels between Modi's actions and those of U.S. President Donald Trump, suggesting both leaders inflict "self-inflicted wounds" on their economies, citing India's demonetization as a past example. The market downturn mirrored global sell-offs prompted by fears of a trade war escalating between the U.S. and China following new tariff implementations and retaliatory measures.

title: Supreme Court collegium recommends transfer of Madhya Pradesh HC Judge to Kerala HC
story_summary: The Supreme Court collegium, presided over by Chief Justice of India Sanjiv Khanna, has recommended the transfer of Justice Sushrut Arvind Dharmadhikari. The proposal is for Justice Dharmadhikari to move from his current position as a Judge in the High Court of Madhya Pradesh to the High Court of Kerala. This recommendation was finalized following collegium meetings held on March 20, March 24, and April 3, 2025. The decision regarding the judicial transfer was officially communicated through a statement released on the Supreme Court's website, outlining the collegium's resolution on the matter as part of judicial administration.

title: Petitioners mention in SC their challenge to Waqf law as fresh pleas pour in
story_summary: Lawyers representing various petitioners challenging the Waqf (Amendment) Act, 2025, made urgent mentions before the Supreme Court on Monday, seeking an early hearing. Chief Justice of India Sanjiv Khanna assured them that the requests would be processed according to the court's established system and listed in due course. This comes as new petitions against the Act continue to be filed, including by the DMK and IUML, particularly after it received Presidential assent. The core arguments in these petitions state that the amendments violate constitutional rights (Articles 14, 15, 25, 26), impose arbitrary restrictions, enhance state control over Waqf properties, undermine Muslim religious autonomy, and discriminate against the community compared to how other religious endowments are governed.

title: Rajasthan MP in CPI(M) Politburo the sole face from North: Who is Amra Ram?
story_summary: Amra Ram, the CPI(M) MP from Sikar, Rajasthan, has been inducted into the party's Politburo, making him the sole representative from North India in the executive body. Ram, 69, is a veteran farmer leader known for his ability to unite diverse groups, notably during the 2017 Sikar farmers' agitation demanding debt waivers and fair prices. He began his political career in student politics in 1978, later becoming a sarpanch and serving multiple terms as an MLA from Dhod and Danta Ramgarh, winning the Best MLA award in 2011. Despite numerous electoral defeats, including six Lok Sabha attempts since the 1990s, his persistence and deep roots in the farmer community of the Shekhawati region propelled his recent victory. His 2024 Lok Sabha win came with significant support from the Congress under the INDIA bloc alliance, capitalizing on anti-BJP sentiment among Jats in Shekhawati.

title: From Gandhi-Patel land, Congress will signal its golden past. But all eyes on what AICC Session holds for future
story_summary: The Congress party is holding a two-day All India Congress Committee (AICC) session in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, aiming to revitalize itself after recent electoral setbacks. Gujarat, a state the party hasn't won since 1995, was chosen symbolically to invoke Mahatma Gandhi and Sardar Patel, seeking to reclaim Patel's legacy from the BJP. This marks the first AICC session in Gujarat since 1961. The extended Working Committee will meet at the Sardar Patel Memorial, reinforcing the message. However, internal expectations remain modest regarding concrete outcomes like organizational reforms, given the poor implementation of resolutions from the 2022 Udaipur meeting. Leaders hope for clearer direction on countering the BJP and the strategy for the INDIA bloc. Resolutions are anticipated on key issues like inflation, unemployment, farmers' issues, and social justice, but the overall goal appears to be boosting morale rather than charting a detailed future course.

title: Prashant Kishor interview: ‘NDA, especially Nitish, is being overestimated and Jan Suraaj being underestimated. We will be a big factor’
story_summary: Political strategist-turned-politician Prashant Kishor, ahead of a rally for his Jan Suraaj party (JSP), outlined his vision for the upcoming Bihar Assembly polls. He identifies a strong public desire for change from the established political order dominated by figures like Lalu Prasad and Nitish Kumar, citing their age and health. Key issues fueling this demand, according to Kishor, include bureaucratic inefficiency (afsarshahi), corruption, migration, poor education, and unemployment. He criticizes both the NDA and INDIA bloc, particularly on the Waqf Act, positioning JSP as a genuine alternative, especially for Muslims. Kishor asserts that JSP is underestimated while the NDA, particularly Nitish Kumar, is overestimated. He believes JSP will field candidates proportionally across communities and become a major factor, influenced heavily by Nitish's perceived declining leadership capacity.

title: ‘Comrades for life’: Meet the new couple in CPI(M) Politburo, Mariam and Ashok Dhawale
story_summary: Mariam Dhawale (64) and Ashok Dhawale (71) have been inducted into the CPI(M) Politburo, the party's highest executive body, following the conclusion of the 24th Party Congress. They represent a new leadership couple as veterans Prakash and Brinda Karat step down due to the party's 75-year age limit. Both Mariam and Ashok have long histories in party activism, starting with the Students' Federation of India (SFI) in Maharashtra in the late 1970s and early 1980s. Ashok, a physician, became the national president of the All India Kisan Sabha (AIKS), while Mariam became the national general secretary of the All India Democratic Women’s Association (AIDWA). They married in 1994, emphasizing their shared political commitment. Though atheists now, Ashok comes from a Hindu background and Mariam from a Muslim one. They maintain they will hold independent views within the Politburo.

title: Waqf Act now sees protests in Manipur: A look at the Meitei Pangals behind the stir
story_summary: Manipur's Muslim community, primarily the Meitei Pangals, held protests against the newly passed Waqf Act in the Imphal Valley. The demonstrations led to the burning of the house of BJP Minority Morcha state president Asker Ali in Thoubal district after he initially supported the legislation; he later retracted his support and opposed the Act. Security has been heightened in response. The Meitei Pangals are Muslims who are part of the larger Meitei ethnic group, tracing their origins to settlers in the 17th century who assimilated Meitei culture and language. They constitute about 8.4% of Manipur's population. Historically, relations with the Hindu Meitei majority have seen tensions, notably the 1993 riots, after which Pangals were granted OBC status. Though not direct participants in the ongoing Meitei-Kuki conflict, they inhabit areas affected by the violence.

title: BJP’s Bihar allies in a fix over support for Waqf law, RJD spots a line of attack
story_summary: The passage of the Waqf Amendment Bill has created political discomfort for the BJP's allies in Bihar, the JD(U) and LJP(RV), ahead of state assembly elections. Their support for the Bill in Parliament has led to internal dissent, with several JD(U) Muslim leaders resigning. The opposition RJD, led by Tejashwi Yadav, is capitalizing on the situation, attacking CM Nitish Kumar's secular credentials and aiming to consolidate Muslim votes. Both JD(U) and LJP(RV) are attempting damage control. JD(U) insists the departing leaders are insignificant and defends the Bill as progressive. LJP(RV) chief Chirag Paswan appealed for understanding from the Muslim community, invoking his father's legacy. While some JD(U) leaders downplay the electoral impact, citing an already diminished Muslim vote share, the RJD believes the issue exposes the allies' compromises and will resonate with voters who value secularism.

title: Why Raj Thackeray may have directed MNS workers to halt Marathi language stir
story_summary: Maharashtra Navnirman Sena (MNS) chief Raj Thackeray instructed his party workers to cease acts of violence associated with his renewed "Mi Marathi" campaign, which urged supporters to confront those refusing to speak Marathi. This directive came shortly after the campaign's launch on Gudi Padwa and followed significant backlash, including assaults on individuals like bank officials. Sources suggest pressure from the BJP-led state government under CM Devendra Fadnavis was a key factor. The BJP reportedly feared alienating North Indian voters, particularly with Bihar elections looming, and worried the violence could tarnish Maharashtra's image as an investment hub aiming for a trillion-dollar economy. Concerns were also raised by industry sectors and bank unions. Thackeray maintained it wasn't a compromise but urged the government to enforce existing Marathi language laws.

title: CPI(M) hits refresh: Old guard out, new leaders in, but the big challenges remain
story_summary: The CPI(M) concluded its national conclave in Madurai by electing M A Baby as its new general secretary and overhauling its Politburo. Eight new members were inducted, replacing veterans like Prakash Karat, Brinda Karat, and Manik Sarkar due to a 75-year age cap (with an exemption for Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan). The new inductees include leaders like Jitendra Choudhury, Amra Ram, Vijoo Krishnan, and Mariam Dhawale, aiming for generational change. The Central Committee also saw 30 new members elected, following a rare contested election which hinted at internal differences, possibly regarding the general secretary choice. Despite this leadership refresh, the CPI(M) faces severe challenges: a shrinking national footprint (only 4 Lok Sabha seats), the need to revive fortunes in former strongholds West Bengal and Tripura, expand its base, and retain power in its last bastion, Kerala. Baby stressed countering the BJP and revitalizing the party.

title: Today in Politics: Rahul to join Kanhaiya’s yatra in Bihar; Amit Shah to hold high-level security review meet in Srinagar
story_summary: Several key political activities are scheduled for Monday, April 7th. Lok Sabha Opposition Leader Rahul Gandhi is set to join Congress leader Kanhaiya Kumar's 'palayan roko, naukri do' (stop migration, give jobs) march in Begusarai, Bihar, mobilizing youth ahead of state elections. Union Home Minister Amit Shah, during his three-day visit to Jammu and Kashmir, will conduct a high-level security review meeting in Srinagar and may visit the International Border in Kathua. His agenda includes assessing security and development progress. Meanwhile, the Karnataka BJP begins a 16-day statewide 'Janaakrosha Yatra' (people's movement) protesting against price rises and the state government's policy of 4% reservation for Muslims in government contracts. This multi-phase agitation aims to cover all districts of Karnataka.

title: KTR interview: ‘Revanth Reddy has no regard for the law … turned Telangana into an Emergency state’
story_summary: Bharat Rashtra Samithi (BRS) working president K T Rama Rao (KTR) launched a sharp critique against Telangana Chief Minister Revanth Reddy and his Congress government. KTR condemned the state's move to auction disputed forest land near the University of Hyderabad, welcoming the Supreme Court's stay order and accusing the government of ignoring environmental and sentimental value. He labeled Reddy a "habitual offender" with no respect for the law, citing recent criticisms from the Supreme Court regarding MLA disqualifications and the K Kavitha bail case. KTR alleged that the government's crackdown on critics, including journalists and social media figures, has turned Telangana into an "Emergency state." He further questioned the Congress government's ability to fulfill its numerous pre-election promises, accusing them of fiscal mismanagement and intellectual bankruptcy after claiming empty coffers.

title: CPI(M) appoints new general secretary: Who is M A Baby?
story_summary: M A Baby, 70, has been elected as the new general secretary of the Communist Party of India (Marxist), CPI(M). He is a senior leader from Kerala and only the second person from the state unit, after E M S Namboodiripad, to hold the party's top position. Baby's political career began in student activism with the SFI and later the youth wing DYFI. He served as a Rajya Sabha MP from 1986 to 1998 and was Kerala's Education Minister from 2006 to 2011. Known as the party's cultural face, he played a key role in initiatives like the Kochi Biennale art exhibition. A self-proclaimed atheist and a Christian face in the Politburo, Baby was inducted into the Central Committee in 1999 and the Politburo in 2012. He takes charge as the CPI(M) faces significant challenges in reviving its national presence.

title: PM Modi and RSS chief Bhagwat’s meeting steadies the boat, clears the air
story_summary: Prime Minister Narendra Modi recently met with RSS chief Mohan Bhagwat at the RSS headquarters in Nagpur, a significant move seen as easing recent strains in the relationship between the BJP and its ideological mentor. It was Modi's first visit to the HQ as PM in 11 years. The meeting occurred after the 2024 elections where the BJP lost its parliamentary majority, partly attributed to reduced RSS ground support following perceived slights like BJP President J P Nadda's comments about the party's self-sufficiency. Modi's visit reaffirmed his RSS roots ('swayamsevak') and acknowledged the BJP's reliance on the Sangh. In return, the RSS leadership signaled renewed backing for Modi. The meeting likely addressed key issues like the selection of the next BJP president and signaled a mutual understanding between Modi and Bhagwat, both turning 75, on the need for stability to pursue shared long-term goals.

title: Kerala’s M A Baby named next CPM general secretary
story_summary: At the conclusion of the CPI(M) party congress in Madurai, M A Baby (70), a veteran leader from Kerala, was named the party's new national general secretary. He succeeds Prakash Karat, who served as interim coordinator after Sitaram Yechury's death. Baby, a former state education minister and Rajya Sabha MP, rose through the party's student (SFI) and youth (DYFI) ranks. His appointment came after Karat proposed his name, although Ashok Dhawale was also suggested by some Polit Bureau members. This leadership change coincides with a significant generational shift in the Politburo, with eight new members inducted as older leaders step down due to age limits. Baby, known for advocating the need to rebuild the party's mass base, takes charge as the CPI(M)'s influence is largely confined to Kerala, where it currently holds power.

title: BJD MP on the party’s Waqf shift: ‘Naveen Patnaik’s advisor is behind it… there is a secret deal with BJP’
story_summary: Biju Janata Dal (BJD) MP Debashish Samantaray abstained from voting on the Waqf Amendment Bill in the Rajya Sabha, citing his dissatisfaction with the party's sudden change in stance. He stated that party president Naveen Patnaik had initially instructed MPs to oppose the Bill, aligning with the party's previously declared position. However, just hours before the vote, floor leader Sasmit Patra announced on social media platform X that there was no whip, allowing a conscience vote. Samantaray blames an unnamed advisor to Patnaik for this last-minute shift, suggesting a possible "conspiracy" or a "secret deal" with the BJP. He criticized Patra for lack of consultation and for publicly claiming to have voted in favour. Samantaray expressed concern that this perceived betrayal of the party's secular stance will severely damage BJD's support among Muslim voters in Odisha.

title: Knives out in Haryana Congress against Hooda as Hariprasad steps up rehaul bid
story_summary: The Haryana Congress remains mired in factionalism following its defeat in the state assembly elections six months ago. New AICC in-charge B K Hariprasad faces the challenge of rebuilding the party organization, which has lacked functional district and block committees for over 15 years. Internal opposition to former CM Bhupinder Singh Hooda and state president Udai Bhan (a Hooda ally) is intensifying, with several leaders demanding their replacement. Figures like Vipin Sangwan and Shamsher Singh Gogi have urged Hariprasad to appoint new leadership and prioritize committed workers over those solely seeking power. They stress the need for a strong grassroots structure. Hooda acknowledges the need for reorganization, expecting progress after the upcoming AICC session. However, past efforts by numerous state in-charges to resolve infighting and build the organization have yielded little success amid the party's decade-long decline.
